    4156                 :     993877 :                             goto out_unlocked;
    4157                 :            :                         }
    4158                 :       4072 :                         break;
    4159                 :            :                     case LockTupleNoKeyExclusive:
    4160         [ +  + ]:    3182817 :                         if (HEAP_XMAX_IS_EXCL_LOCKED(infomask))
    4161                 :            :                         {
    4162                 :    2773674 :                             result = TM_Ok;
    4163                 :    2773674 :                             goto out_unlocked;
    4164                 :            :                         }
    4165                 :     409143 :                         break;
    4166                 :            :                     case LockTupleExclusive:
    4167 [ +  + ][ +  + ]:    2135790 :                         if (HEAP_XMAX_IS_EXCL_LOCKED(infomask) &&
    4168                 :    2126142 :                             infomask2 & HEAP_KEYS_UPDATED)
    4169                 :            :                         {
    4170                 :    1020084 :                             result = TM_Ok;
    4171                 :    1020084 :                             goto out_unlocked;
    4172                 :            :                         }
    4173                 :    1115706 :                         break;
    4174                 :            :                 }
    4175                 :            :             }
    4176                 :            :         }
    4177                 :            : 
    4178                 :            :         /*
    4179                 :            :          * Initially assume that we will have to wait for the locking
    4180                 :            :          * transaction(s) to finish.  We check various cases below in which
    4181                 :            :          * this can be turned off.
    4182                 :            :          */
    4183                 :   22463599 :         require_sleep = true;
    4184         [ +  + ]:   22463599 :         if (mode == LockTupleKeyShare)
    4185                 :            :         {
    4186                 :            :             /*
    4187                 :            :              * If we're requesting KeyShare, and there's no update present, we
    4188                 :            :              * don't need to wait.  Even if there is an update, we can still
    4189                 :            :              * continue if the key hasn't been modified.
    4190                 :            :              *
    4191                 :            :              * However, if there are updates, we need to walk the update chain
    4192                 :            :              * to mark future versions of the row as locked, too.  That way,
    4193                 :            :              * if somebody deletes that future version, we're protected
    4194                 :            :              * against the key going away.  This locking of future versions
    4195                 :            :              * could block momentarily, if a concurrent transaction is
    4196                 :            :              * deleting a key; or it could return a value to the effect that
    4197                 :            :              * the transaction deleting the key has already committed.  So we
    4198                 :            :              * do this before re-locking the buffer; otherwise this would be
    4199                 :            :              * prone to deadlocks.
    4200                 :            :              *
    4201                 :            :              * Note that the TID we're locking was grabbed before we unlocked
    4202                 :            :              * the buffer.  For it to change while we're not looking, the
    4203                 :            :              * other properties we're testing for below after re-locking the
    4204                 :            :              * buffer would also change, in which case we would restart this
    4205                 :            :              * loop above.
    4206                 :            :              */
    4207         [ +  + ]:   19932294 :             if (!(infomask2 & HEAP_KEYS_UPDATED))

    4214                 :            :                  * If there are updates, follow the update chain; bail out if

    4350                 :            :          * committed, then sleeping cannot possibly do any good: if we're
    4351                 :            :          * required to sleep, get out to raise an error instead.
    4352                 :            :          *

    4367                 :            :              * for the tuple.  We must do this even if we are share-locking,
    4368                 :            :              * but not if we already have a weaker lock on the tuple.
    4369                 :            :              *
    4370                 :            :              * If we are forced to "start over" below, we keep the tuple lock;

    4603                 :            :      * Make sure there is no forward chain link in t_ctid.  Note that in the
    4604                 :            :      * cases where the tuple has been updated, we must not overwrite t_ctid,
    4605                 :            :      * because it was set by the updater.  Moreover, if the tuple has been
    4606                 :            :      * updated, we need to follow the update chain to lock the new versions of
    4607                 :            :      * the tuple as well.
    4608                 :            :      */
    4609 [ +  + ][ -  + ]:   44512779 :     if (HEAP_XMAX_IS_LOCKED_ONLY(new_infomask))
    4610                 :   43403498 :         tuple->t_data->t_ctid = *tid;
    4611                 :            : 
    4612                 :            :     /* Clear only the all-frozen bit on visibility map if needed */
    4613   [ +  +  -  + ]:   44904316 :     if (PageIsAllVisible(page) &&
    4614                 :     391537 :         visibilitymap_clear(relation, block, vmbuffer,
    4615                 :            :                             VISIBILITYMAP_ALL_FROZEN))
    4616                 :          0 :         cleared_all_frozen = true;
    4617                 :            : 
    4618                 :            : 
    4619                 :   44512779 :     MarkBufferDirty(*buffer);
    4620                 :            : 
    4621                 :            :     /*
    4622                 :            :      * XLOG stuff.  You might think that we don't need an XLOG record because
    4623                 :            :      * there is no state change worth restoring after a crash.  You would be
    4624                 :            :      * wrong however: we have just written either a TransactionId or a
    4625                 :            :      * MultiXactId that may never have been seen on disk before, and we need
    4626                 :            :      * to make sure that there are XLOG entries covering those ID numbers.
    4627                 :            :      * Else the same IDs might be re-used after a crash, which would be
    4628                 :            :      * disastrous if this page made it to disk before the crash.  Essentially
    4629                 :            :      * we have to enforce the WAL log-before-data rule even in this case.
    4630                 :            :      * (Also, in a PITR log-shipping or 2PC environment, we have to have XLOG
    4631                 :            :      * entries for everything anyway.)
    4632                 :            :      */
    4633         [ +  - ]:   44512779 :     if (RelationNeedsWAL(relation))
    4634                 :            :     {
    4635                 :            :         xl_heap_lock xlrec;
    4636                 :            :         XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    4637                 :            : 
    4638                 :   44512779 :         XLogBeginInsert();
    4639                 :   44512779 :         XLogRegisterBuffer(0, *buffer, REGBUF_STANDARD);
    4640                 :            :

    4672                 :            :      * Now that we have successfully marked the tuple as locked, we can

    4680                 :            : 
    4681                 :            : /*
    4682                 :            :  * Acquire heavyweight lock on the given tuple, in preparation for acquiring
    4683                 :            :  * its normal, Xmax-based tuple lock.
    4684                 :            :  *
    4685                 :            :  * have_tuple_lock is an input and output parameter: on input, it indicates
    4686                 :            :  * whether the lock has previously been acquired (and this function does
    4687                 :            :  * nothing in that case).  If this function returns success, have_tuple_lock
    4688                 :            :  * has been flipped to true.
    4689                 :            :  *
    4690                 :            :  * Returns false if it was unable to obtain the lock; this can only happen if
    4691                 :            :  * wait_policy is Skip.
    4692                 :            :  */
    4693                 :            : static bool
    4694                 :     149182 : heap_acquire_tuplock(Relation relation, ItemPointer tid, LockTupleMode mode,
    4695                 :            :                      LockWaitPolicy wait_policy, bool *have_tuple_lock)
    4696                 :            : {
    4697         [ +  + ]:     149182 :     if (*have_tuple_lock)
    4698                 :      16414 :         return true;
    4699                 :            : 
    4700   [ +  -  -  - ]:     132768 :     switch (wait_policy)
    4701                 :            :     {
    4702                 :            :         case LockWaitBlock:
    4703                 :     132768 :             LockTupleTuplock(relation, tid, mode);
    4704                 :     130125 :             break;
    4705                 :            : 
    4706                 :            :         case LockWaitSkip:
    4707         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (!ConditionalLockTupleTuplock(relation, tid, mode))
    4708                 :          0 :                 return false;
    4709                 :          0 :             break;
    4710                 :            : 
    4711                 :            :         case LockWaitError:
    4712         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (!ConditionalLockTupleTuplock(relation, tid, mode))
    4713         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 ereport(ERROR,
    4714                 :            :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_LOCK_NOT_AVAILABLE),
    4715                 :            :                          errmsg("could not obtain lock on row in relation \"%s\"",
    4716                 :            :                                 RelationGetRelationName(relation))));
    4717                 :          0 :             break;
    4718                 :            :     }
    4719                 :     130125 :     *have_tuple_lock = true;
    4720                 :            : 
    4721                 :     130125 :     return true;
    4722                 :            : }
    4723                 :            : 
    4724                 :            : /*
    4725                 :            :  * Given an original set of Xmax and infomask, and a transaction (identified by
    4726                 :            :  * add_to_xmax) acquiring a new lock of some mode, compute the new Xmax and
    4727                 :            :  * corresponding infomasks to use on the tuple.
    4728                 :            :  *
    4729                 :            :  * Note that this might have side effects such as creating a new MultiXactId.
    4730                 :            :  *
    4731                 :            :  * Most callers will have called HeapTupleSatisfiesUpdate before this function;
    4732                 :            :  * that will have set the HEAP_XMAX_INVALID bit if the xmax was a MultiXactId
    4733                 :            :  * but it was not running anymore. There is a race condition, which is that the
    4734                 :            :  * MultiXactId may have finished since then, but that uncommon case is handled
    4735                 :            :  * either here, or within MultiXactIdExpand.
    4736                 :            :  *
    4737                 :            :  * There is a similar race condition possible when the old xmax was a regular
    4738                 :            :  * TransactionId.  We test TransactionIdIsInProgress again just to narrow the
    4739                 :            :  * window, but it's still possible to end up creating an unnecessary
    4740                 :            :  * MultiXactId.  Fortunately this is harmless.
    4741                 :            :  */
    4742                 :            : static void
    4743                 :   46353163 : compute_new_xmax_infomask(TransactionId xmax, uint16 old_infomask,
    4744                 :            :                           uint16 old_infomask2, TransactionId add_to_xmax,

    4746                 :            :                           TransactionId *result_xmax, uint16 *result_infomask,
    4747                 :            :                           uint16 *result_infomask2)

    4764                 :            :          * because there are several blocks below that come back to this one

    4813                 :            :          * A multixact together with LOCK_ONLY set but neither lock bit set
    4814                 :            :          * (i.e. a pg_upgraded share locked tuple) cannot possibly be running
    4815                 :            :          * anymore.  This check is critical for databases upgraded by
    4816                 :            :          * pg_upgrade; both MultiXactIdIsRunning and MultiXactIdExpand assume

    4827                 :            :          * If the XMAX is already a MultiXactId, then we need to expand it to

    4829                 :            :          * all gone, we can do away with the IS_MULTI bit and just set
    4830                 :            :          * add_to_xmax as the only locker/updater.  If all lockers are gone
    4831                 :            :          * and we have an updater that aborted, we can also do without a

    4833                 :            :          *

    5008                 :            : /*
    5009                 :            :  * Subroutine for heap_lock_updated_tuple_rec.
    5010                 :            :  *
    5011                 :            :  * Given a hypothetical multixact status held by the transaction identified
    5012                 :            :  * with the given xid, does the current transaction need to wait, fail, or can
    5013                 :            :  * it continue if it wanted to acquire a lock of the given mode?  "needwait"
    5014                 :            :  * is set to true if waiting is necessary; if it can continue, then TM_Ok is
    5015                 :            :  * returned.  If the lock is already held by the current transaction, return
    5016                 :            :  * TM_SelfModified.  In case of a conflict with another transaction, a
    5017                 :            :  * different HeapTupleSatisfiesUpdate return code is returned.
    5018                 :            :  *
    5019                 :            :  * The held status is said to be hypothetical because it might correspond to a
    5020                 :            :  * lock held by a single Xid, i.e. not a real MultiXactId; we express it this
    5021                 :            :  * way for simplicity of API.
    5022                 :            :  */
    5023                 :            : static TM_Result
    5024                 :   11019854 : test_lockmode_for_conflict(MultiXactStatus status, TransactionId xid,
    5025                 :            :                            LockTupleMode mode, HeapTuple tup,
    5026                 :            :                            bool *needwait)
    5027                 :            : {
    5028                 :            :     MultiXactStatus wantedstatus;
    5029                 :            : 
    5030                 :   11019854 :     *needwait = false;
    5031                 :   11019854 :     wantedstatus = get_mxact_status_for_lock(mode, false);
    5032                 :            : 
    5033                 :            :     /*
    5034                 :            :      * Note: we *must* check TransactionIdIsInProgress before
    5035                 :            :      * TransactionIdDidAbort/Commit; see comment at top of heapam_visibility.c
    5036                 :            :      * for an explanation.
    5037                 :            :      */
    5038         [ +  + ]:   11019854 :     if (TransactionIdIsCurrentTransactionId(xid))
    5039                 :            :     {
    5040                 :            :         /*
    5041                 :            :          * The tuple has already been locked by our own transaction.  This is
    5042                 :            :          * very rare but can happen if multiple transactions are trying to
    5043                 :            :          * lock an ancient version of the same tuple.
    5044                 :            :          */
    5045                 :         18 :         return TM_SelfModified;
    5046                 :            :     }
    5047         [ +  + ]:   11019836 :     else if (TransactionIdIsInProgress(xid))
    5048                 :            :     {
    5049                 :            :         /*
    5050                 :            :          * If the locking transaction is running, what we do depends on
    5051                 :            :          * whether the lock modes conflict: if they do, then we must wait for
    5052                 :            :          * it to finish; otherwise we can fall through to lock this tuple
    5053                 :            :          * version without waiting.
    5054                 :            :          */
    5055         [ -  + ]:   10066212 :         if (DoLockModesConflict(LOCKMODE_from_mxstatus(status),
    5056                 :   10066212 :                                 LOCKMODE_from_mxstatus(wantedstatus)))
    5057                 :            :         {
    5058                 :          0 :             *needwait = true;
    5059                 :            :         }
    5060                 :            : 
    5061                 :            :         /*
    5062                 :            :          * If we set needwait above, then this value doesn't matter;
    5063                 :            :          * otherwise, this value signals to caller that it's okay to proceed.
    5064                 :            :          */
    5065                 :   10066212 :         return TM_Ok;
    5066                 :            :     }
    5067         [ +  + ]:     953624 :     else if (TransactionIdDidAbort(xid))
    5068                 :     871192 :         return TM_Ok;
    5069         [ +  - ]:      82432 :     else if (TransactionIdDidCommit(xid))
    5070                 :            :     {
    5071                 :            :         /*
    5072                 :            :          * The other transaction committed.  If it was only a locker, then the
    5073                 :            :          * lock is completely gone now and we can return success; but if it
    5074                 :            :          * was an update, then what we do depends on whether the two lock
    5075                 :            :          * modes conflict.  If they conflict, then we must report error to
    5076                 :            :          * caller. But if they don't, we can fall through to allow the current
    5077                 :            :          * transaction to lock the tuple.
    5078                 :            :          *
    5079                 :            :          * Note: the reason we worry about ISUPDATE here is because as soon as
    5080                 :            :          * a transaction ends, all its locks are gone and meaningless, and
    5081                 :            :          * thus we can ignore them; whereas its updates persist.  In the
    5082                 :            :          * TransactionIdIsInProgress case, above, we don't need to check
    5083                 :            :          * because we know the lock is still "alive" and thus a conflict needs
    5084                 :            :          * always be checked.
    5085                 :            :          */
    5086         [ +  + ]:      82432 :         if (!ISUPDATE_from_mxstatus(status))
    5087                 :      65856 :             return TM_Ok;
    5088                 :            : 
    5089         [ +  + ]:      16576 :         if (DoLockModesConflict(LOCKMODE_from_mxstatus(status),
    5090                 :      16576 :                                 LOCKMODE_from_mxstatus(wantedstatus)))
    5091                 :            :         {
    5092                 :            :             /* bummer */
    5093 [ -  + ][ #  # ]:          1 :             if (!ItemPointerEquals(&tup->t_self, &tup->t_data->t_ctid) ||
    5094         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 HeapTupleHeaderIndicatesMovedPartitions(tup->t_data))
    5095                 :          1 :                 return TM_Updated;
    5096                 :            :             else
    5097                 :          0 :                 return TM_Deleted;
    5098                 :            :         }
    5099                 :            : 
    5100                 :      16575 :         return TM_Ok;
    5101                 :            :     }
    5102                 :            : 
    5103                 :            :     /* Not in progress, not aborted, not committed -- must have crashed */
    5104                 :          0 :     return TM_Ok;
    5105                 :            : }
    5106                 :            : 
    5107                 :            : 
    5108                 :            : /*
    5109                 :            :  * Recursive part of heap_lock_updated_tuple
    5110                 :            :  *
    5111                 :            :  * Fetch the tuple pointed to by tid in rel, and mark it as locked by the given
    5112                 :            :  * xid with the given mode; if this tuple is updated, recurse to lock the new
    5113                 :            :  * version as well.
    5114                 :            :  */
    5115                 :            : static TM_Result

    5177                 :            :          * If we didn't pin the visibility map page and the page has become

    5181                 :            :          *
    5182                 :            :          * Note: in some paths through this function, we will reach here

    5425                 :            : 
    5426                 :            :     result = TM_Ok;
    5427                 :            : 
    5428                 :            : out_locked:
    5429                 :    1241698 :     UnlockReleaseBuffer(buf);
    5430                 :            : 
    5431                 :            : out_unlocked:
    5432         [ -  + ]:    1243324 :     if (vmbuffer != InvalidBuffer)
    5433                 :          0 :         ReleaseBuffer(vmbuffer);
    5434                 :            : 
    5435                 :    1243324 :     return result;
    5436                 :            : }
    5437                 :            : 
    5438                 :            : /*
    5439                 :            :  * heap_lock_updated_tuple
    5440                 :            :  *      Follow update chain when locking an updated tuple, acquiring locks (row
    5441                 :            :  *      marks) on the updated versions.
    5442                 :            :  *
    5443                 :            :  * The initial tuple is assumed to be already locked.
    5444                 :            :  *
    5445                 :            :  * This function doesn't check visibility, it just unconditionally marks the
    5446                 :            :  * tuple(s) as locked.  If any tuple in the updated chain is being deleted
    5447                 :            :  * concurrently (or updated with the key being modified), sleep until the
    5448                 :            :  * transaction doing it is finished.
    5449                 :            :  *
    5450                 :            :  * Note that we don't acquire heavyweight tuple locks on the tuples we walk
    5451                 :            :  * when we have to wait for other transactions to release them, as opposed to
    5452                 :            :  * what heap_lock_tuple does.  The reason is that having more than one
    5453                 :            :  * transaction walking the chain is probably uncommon enough that risk of
    5454                 :            :  * starvation is not likely: one of the preconditions for being here is that
    5455                 :            :  * the snapshot in use predates the update that created this tuple (because we
    5456                 :            :  * started at an earlier version of the tuple), but at the same time such a
    5457                 :            :  * transaction cannot be using repeatable read or serializable isolation
    5458                 :            :  * levels, because that would lead to a serializability failure.
    5459                 :            :  */
    5460                 :            : static TM_Result
    5461                 :    1243532 : heap_lock_updated_tuple(Relation rel, HeapTuple tuple, ItemPointer ctid,
    5462                 :            :                         TransactionId xid, LockTupleMode mode)
    5463                 :            : {
    5464                 :            :     /*
    5465                 :            :      * If the tuple has not been updated, or has moved into another partition
    5466                 :            :      * (effectively a delete) stop here.
    5467                 :            :      */
    5468         [ -  + ]:    2487064 :     if (!HeapTupleHeaderIndicatesMovedPartitions(tuple->t_data) &&
           [ #  #  +  + ]
    5469                 :    1243532 :         !ItemPointerEquals(&tuple->t_self, ctid))
    5470                 :            :     {
    5471                 :            :         /*
    5472                 :            :          * If this is the first possibly-multixact-able operation in the
    5473                 :            :          * current transaction, set my per-backend OldestMemberMXactId
    5474                 :            :          * setting. We can be certain that the transaction will never become a
    5475                 :            :          * member of any older MultiXactIds than that.  (We have to do this
    5476                 :            :          * even if we end up just using our own TransactionId below, since
    5477                 :            :          * some other backend could incorporate our XID into a MultiXact
    5478                 :            :          * immediately afterwards.)
    5479                 :            :          */
    5480                 :    1243324 :         MultiXactIdSetOldestMember();
    5481                 :            : 
    5482                 :    1243324 :         return heap_lock_updated_tuple_rec(rel, ctid, xid, mode);
    5483                 :            :     }
    5484                 :            : 
    5485                 :            :     /* nothing to lock */
    5486                 :        208 :     return TM_Ok;
    5487                 :            : }
    5488                 :            : 
    5489                 :            : /*
    5490                 :            :  *  heap_finish_speculative - mark speculative insertion as successful
    5491                 :            :  *
    5492                 :            :  * To successfully finish a speculative insertion we have to clear speculative
    5493                 :            :  * token from tuple.  To do so the t_ctid field, which will contain a
    5494                 :            :  * speculative token value, is modified in place to point to the tuple itself,
    5495                 :            :  * which is characteristic of a newly inserted ordinary tuple.
    5496                 :            :  *
    5497                 :            :  * NB: It is not ok to commit without either finishing or aborting a
    5498                 :            :  * speculative insertion.  We could treat speculative tuples of committed
    5499                 :            :  * transactions implicitly as completed, but then we would have to be prepared
    5500                 :            :  * to deal with speculative tokens on committed tuples.  That wouldn't be
    5501                 :            :  * difficult - no-one looks at the ctid field of a tuple with invalid xmax -
    5502                 :            :  * but clearing the token at completion isn't very expensive either.
    5503                 :            :  * An explicit confirmation WAL record also makes logical decoding simpler.
    5504                 :            :  */
    5505                 :            : void
    5506                 :          0 : heap_finish_speculative(Relation relation, ItemPointer tid)
    5507                 :            : {
    5508                 :            :     Buffer      buffer;
    5509                 :            :     Page        page;
    5510                 :            :     OffsetNumber offnum;
    5511                 :          0 :     ItemId      lp = NULL;
    5512                 :            :     HeapTupleHeader htup;
    5513                 :            : 
    5514                 :          0 :     buffer = ReadBuffer(relation, ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(tid));
    5515                 :          0 :     LockBuffer(buffer, BUFFER_LOCK_EXCLUSIVE);
    5516         [ #  # ]:          0 :     page = (Page) BufferGetPage(buffer);
    5517                 :            : 
    5518                 :          0 :     offnum = ItemPointerGetOffsetNumber(tid);
    5519 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     if (PageGetMaxOffsetNumber(page) >= offnum)
    5520                 :          0 :         lp = PageGetItemId(page, offnum);
    5521                 :            : 
    5522 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     if (PageGetMaxOffsetNumber(page) < offnum || !ItemIdIsNormal(lp))
                 [ #  # ]
    5523                 :          0 :         elog(ERROR, "invalid lp");
    5524                 :            : 
    5525                 :          0 :     htup = (HeapTupleHeader) PageGetItem(page, lp);
    5526                 :            : 
    5527                 :            :     /* SpecTokenOffsetNumber should be distinguishable from any real offset */
    5528                 :            :     StaticAssertStmt(MaxOffsetNumber < SpecTokenOffsetNumber,
    5529                 :            :                      "invalid speculative token constant");
    5530                 :            : 
    5531                 :            :     /* NO EREPORT(ERROR) from here till changes are logged */
    5532                 :          0 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    5533                 :            : 
    5534                 :            :     Assert(HeapTupleHeaderIsSpeculative(htup));
    5535                 :            : 
    5536                 :          0 :     MarkBufferDirty(buffer);
    5537                 :            : 
    5538                 :            :     /*
    5539                 :            :      * Replace the speculative insertion token with a real t_ctid, pointing to
    5540                 :            :      * itself like it does on regular tuples.
    5541                 :            :      */
    5542                 :          0 :     htup->t_ctid = *tid;
    5543                 :            : 
    5544                 :            :     /* XLOG stuff */
    5545         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (RelationNeedsWAL(relation))
    5546                 :            :     {
    5547                 :            :         xl_heap_confirm xlrec;
    5548                 :            :         XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    5549                 :            : 
    5550                 :          0 :         xlrec.offnum = ItemPointerGetOffsetNumber(tid);
    5551                 :            : 
    5552                 :          0 :         XLogBeginInsert();
    5553                 :            : 
    5554                 :            :         /* We want the same filtering on this as on a plain insert */
    5555                 :          0 :         XLogSetRecordFlags(XLOG_INCLUDE_ORIGIN);
    5556                 :            : 
    5557                 :          0 :         XLogRegisterData((char *) &xlrec, SizeOfHeapConfirm);
    5558                 :          0 :         XLogRegisterBuffer(0, buffer, REGBUF_STANDARD);
    5559                 :            : 
    5560                 :          0 :         recptr = XLogInsert(RM_HEAP_ID, XLOG_HEAP_CONFIRM);
    5561                 :            : 
    5562                 :          0 :         PageSetLSN(page, recptr);
    5563                 :            :     }
    5564                 :            : 
    5565                 :          0 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    5566                 :            : 
    5567                 :          0 :     UnlockReleaseBuffer(buffer);
    5568                 :          0 : }
    5569                 :            : 
    5570                 :            : /*
    5571                 :            :  *  heap_abort_speculative - kill a speculatively inserted tuple
    5572                 :            :  *
    5573                 :            :  * Marks a tuple that was speculatively inserted in the same command as dead,
    5574                 :            :  * by setting its xmin as invalid.  That makes it immediately appear as dead
    5575                 :            :  * to all transactions, including our own.  In particular, it makes
    5576                 :            :  * HeapTupleSatisfiesDirty() regard the tuple as dead, so that another backend
    5577                 :            :  * inserting a duplicate key value won't unnecessarily wait for our whole
    5578                 :            :  * transaction to finish (it'll just wait for our speculative insertion to
    5579                 :            :  * finish).
    5580                 :            :  *
    5581                 :            :  * Killing the tuple prevents "unprincipled deadlocks", which are deadlocks
    5582                 :            :  * that arise due to a mutual dependency that is not user visible.  By
    5583                 :            :  * definition, unprincipled deadlocks cannot be prevented by the user
    5584                 :            :  * reordering lock acquisition in client code, because the implementation level
    5585                 :            :  * lock acquisitions are not under the user's direct control.  If speculative
    5586                 :            :  * inserters did not take this precaution, then under high concurrency they
    5587                 :            :  * could deadlock with each other, which would not be acceptable.
    5588                 :            :  *
    5589                 :            :  * This is somewhat redundant with heap_delete, but we prefer to have a
    5590                 :            :  * dedicated routine with stripped down requirements.  Note that this is also
    5591                 :            :  * used to delete the TOAST tuples created during speculative insertion.
    5592                 :            :  *
    5593                 :            :  * This routine does not affect logical decoding as it only looks at
    5594                 :            :  * confirmation records.
    5595                 :            :  */
    5596                 :            : void
    5597                 :          0 : heap_abort_speculative(Relation relation, ItemPointer tid)
    5598                 :            : {
    5599                 :          0 :     TransactionId xid = GetCurrentTransactionId();
    5600                 :            :     ItemId      lp;
    5601                 :            :     HeapTupleData tp;
    5602                 :            :     Page        page;
    5603                 :            :     BlockNumber block;
    5604                 :            :     Buffer      buffer;
    5605                 :            :     TransactionId prune_xid;
    5606                 :            : 
    5607                 :            :     Assert(ItemPointerIsValid(tid));
    5608                 :            : 
    5609                 :          0 :     block = ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(tid);
    5610                 :          0 :     buffer = ReadBuffer(relation, block);
    5611         [ #  # ]:          0 :     page = BufferGetPage(buffer);
    5612                 :            : 
    5613                 :          0 :     LockBuffer(buffer, BUFFER_LOCK_EXCLUSIVE);
    5614                 :            : 
    5615                 :            :     /*
    5616                 :            :      * Page can't be all visible, we just inserted into it, and are still
    5617                 :            :      * running.
    5618                 :            :      */
    5619                 :            :     Assert(!PageIsAllVisible(page));
    5620                 :            : 
    5621                 :          0 :     lp = PageGetItemId(page, ItemPointerGetOffsetNumber(tid));
    5622                 :            :     Assert(ItemIdIsNormal(lp));
    5623                 :            : 
    5624                 :          0 :     tp.t_tableOid = RelationGetRelid(relation);
    5625                 :          0 :     tp.t_data = (HeapTupleHeader) PageGetItem(page, lp);
    5626                 :          0 :     tp.t_len = ItemIdGetLength(lp);
    5627                 :          0 :     tp.t_self = *tid;
    5628                 :            : 
    5629                 :            :     /*
    5630                 :            :      * Sanity check that the tuple really is a speculatively inserted tuple,
    5631                 :            :      * inserted by us.
    5632                 :            :      */
    5633         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (tp.t_data->t_choice.t_heap.t_xmin != xid)
    5634                 :          0 :         elog(ERROR, "attempted to kill a tuple inserted by another transaction");
    5635 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     if (!(IsToastRelation(relation) || HeapTupleHeaderIsSpeculative(tp.t_data)))
    5636                 :          0 :         elog(ERROR, "attempted to kill a non-speculative tuple");
    5637                 :            :     Assert(!HeapTupleHeaderIsHeapOnly(tp.t_data));
    5638                 :            : 
    5639                 :            :     /*
    5640                 :            :      * No need to check for serializable conflicts here.  There is never a
    5641                 :            :      * need for a combocid, either.  No need to extract replica identity, or
    5642                 :            :      * do anything special with infomask bits.
    5643                 :            :      */
    5644                 :            : 
    5645                 :          0 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    5646                 :            : 
    5647                 :            :     /*
    5648                 :            :      * The tuple will become DEAD immediately.  Flag that this page is a
    5649                 :            :      * candidate for pruning by setting xmin to TransactionXmin. While not
    5650                 :            :      * immediately prunable, it is the oldest xid we can cheaply determine
    5651                 :            :      * that's safe against wraparound / being older than the table's
    5652                 :            :      * relfrozenxid.  To defend against the unlikely case of a new relation
    5653                 :            :      * having a newer relfrozenxid than our TransactionXmin, use relfrozenxid
    5654                 :            :      * if so (vacuum can't subsequently move relfrozenxid to beyond
    5655                 :            :      * TransactionXmin, so there's no race here).
    5656                 :            :      */
    5657                 :            :     Assert(TransactionIdIsValid(TransactionXmin));
    5658         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (TransactionIdPrecedes(TransactionXmin, relation->rd_rel->relfrozenxid))
    5659                 :          0 :         prune_xid = relation->rd_rel->relfrozenxid;
    5660                 :            :     else
    5661                 :          0 :         prune_xid = TransactionXmin;
    5662 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     PageSetPrunable(page, prune_xid);
    5663                 :            : 
    5664                 :            :     /* store transaction information of xact deleting the tuple */
    5665                 :          0 :     tp.t_data->t_infomask &= ~(HEAP_XMAX_BITS | HEAP_MOVED);
    5666                 :          0 :     tp.t_data->t_infomask2 &= ~HEAP_KEYS_UPDATED;
    5667                 :            : 
    5668                 :            :     /*
    5669                 :            :      * Set the tuple header xmin to InvalidTransactionId.  This makes the
    5670                 :            :      * tuple immediately invisible everyone.  (In particular, to any
    5671                 :            :      * transactions waiting on the speculative token, woken up later.)
    5672                 :            :      */
    5673                 :          0 :     HeapTupleHeaderSetXmin(tp.t_data, InvalidTransactionId);
    5674                 :            : 
    5675                 :            :     /* Clear the speculative insertion token too */
    5676                 :          0 :     tp.t_data->t_ctid = tp.t_self;
    5677                 :            : 
    5678                 :          0 :     MarkBufferDirty(buffer);
    5679                 :            : 
    5680                 :            :     /*
    5681                 :            :      * XLOG stuff
    5682                 :            :      *
    5683                 :            :      * The WAL records generated here match heap_delete().  The same recovery
    5684                 :            :      * routines are used.
    5685                 :            :      */
    5686         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (RelationNeedsWAL(relation))
    5687                 :            :     {
    5688                 :            :         xl_heap_delete xlrec;
    5689                 :            :         XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    5690                 :            : 
    5691                 :          0 :         xlrec.flags = XLH_DELETE_IS_SUPER;
    5692                 :          0 :         xlrec.infobits_set = compute_infobits(tp.t_data->t_infomask,
    5693                 :          0 :                                               tp.t_data->t_infomask2);
    5694                 :          0 :         xlrec.offnum = ItemPointerGetOffsetNumber(&tp.t_self);
    5695                 :          0 :         xlrec.xmax = xid;
    5696                 :            : 
    5697                 :          0 :         XLogBeginInsert();
    5698                 :          0 :         XLogRegisterData((char *) &xlrec, SizeOfHeapDelete);
    5699                 :          0 :         XLogRegisterBuffer(0, buffer, REGBUF_STANDARD);
    5700                 :            : 
    5701                 :            :         /* No replica identity & replication origin logged */
    5702                 :            : 
    5703                 :          0 :         recptr = XLogInsert(RM_HEAP_ID, XLOG_HEAP_DELETE);
    5704                 :            : 
    5705                 :          0 :         PageSetLSN(page, recptr);
    5706                 :            :     }
    5707                 :            : 
    5708                 :          0 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    5709                 :            : 
    5710                 :          0 :     LockBuffer(buffer, BUFFER_LOCK_UNLOCK);
    5711                 :            : 
    5712         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (HeapTupleHasExternal(&tp))
    5713                 :            :     {
    5714                 :            :         Assert(!IsToastRelation(relation));
    5715                 :          0 :         toast_delete(relation, &tp, true);
    5716                 :            :     }
    5717                 :            : 
    5718                 :            :     /*
    5719                 :            :      * Never need to mark tuple for invalidation, since catalogs don't support
    5720                 :            :      * speculative insertion
    5721                 :            :      */
    5722                 :            : 
    5723                 :            :     /* Now we can release the buffer */
    5724                 :          0 :     ReleaseBuffer(buffer);
    5725                 :            : 
    5726                 :            :     /* count deletion, as we counted the insertion too */
    5727                 :          0 :     pgstat_count_heap_delete(relation);
    5728                 :          0 : }
    5729                 :            : 
    5730                 :            : /*
    5731                 :            :  * heap_inplace_update - update a tuple "in place" (ie, overwrite it)
    5732                 :            :  *
    5733                 :            :  * Overwriting violates both MVCC and transactional safety, so the uses
    5734                 :            :  * of this function in Postgres are extremely limited.  Nonetheless we
    5735                 :            :  * find some places to use it.
    5736                 :            :  *
    5737                 :            :  * The tuple cannot change size, and therefore it's reasonable to assume
    5738                 :            :  * that its null bitmap (if any) doesn't change either.  So we just
    5739                 :            :  * overwrite the data portion of the tuple without touching the null
    5740                 :            :  * bitmap or any of the header fields.
    5741                 :            :  *
    5742                 :            :  * tuple is an in-memory tuple structure containing the data to be written
    5743                 :            :  * over the target tuple.  Also, tuple->t_self identifies the target tuple.
    5744                 :            :  */
    5745                 :            : void
    5746                 :      10737 : heap_inplace_update(Relation relation, HeapTuple tuple)
    5747                 :            : {
    5748                 :            :     Buffer      buffer;
    5749                 :            :     Page        page;
    5750                 :            :     OffsetNumber offnum;
    5751                 :      10737 :     ItemId      lp = NULL;
    5752                 :            :     HeapTupleHeader htup;
    5753                 :            :     uint32      oldlen;
    5754                 :            :     uint32      newlen;
    5755                 :            : 
    5756                 :            :     /*
    5757                 :            :      * For now, parallel operations are required to be strictly read-only.
    5758                 :            :      * Unlike a regular update, this should never create a combo CID, so it
    5759                 :            :      * might be possible to relax this restriction, but not without more
    5760                 :            :      * thought and testing.  It's not clear that it would be useful, anyway.
    5761                 :            :      */
    5762         [ -  + ]:      10737 :     if (IsInParallelMode())
    5763         [ #  # ]:          0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    5764                 :            :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_TRANSACTION_STATE),
    5765                 :            :                  errmsg("cannot update tuples during a parallel operation")));
    5766                 :            : 
    5767                 :      10737 :     buffer = ReadBuffer(relation, ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(&(tuple->t_self)));
    5768                 :      10737 :     LockBuffer(buffer, BUFFER_LOCK_EXCLUSIVE);
    5769         [ -  + ]:      10737 :     page = (Page) BufferGetPage(buffer);
    5770                 :            : 
    5771                 :      10737 :     offnum = ItemPointerGetOffsetNumber(&(tuple->t_self));
    5772 [ +  - ][ +  - ]:      10737 :     if (PageGetMaxOffsetNumber(page) >= offnum)
    5773                 :      10737 :         lp = PageGetItemId(page, offnum);
    5774                 :            : 
    5775 [ +  - ][ +  - ]:      10737 :     if (PageGetMaxOffsetNumber(page) < offnum || !ItemIdIsNormal(lp))
                 [ -  + ]
    5776                 :          0 :         elog(ERROR, "invalid lp");
    5777                 :            : 
    5778                 :      10737 :     htup = (HeapTupleHeader) PageGetItem(page, lp);
    5779                 :            : 
    5780                 :      10737 :     oldlen = ItemIdGetLength(lp) - htup->t_hoff;
    5781                 :      10737 :     newlen = tuple->t_len - tuple->t_data->t_hoff;
    5782 [ +  - ][ -  + ]:      10737 :     if (oldlen != newlen || htup->t_hoff != tuple->t_data->t_hoff)
    5783                 :          0 :         elog(ERROR, "wrong tuple length");
    5784                 :            : 
    5785                 :            :     /* NO EREPORT(ERROR) from here till changes are logged */
    5786                 :      10737 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    5787                 :            : 
    5788                 :      32211 :     memcpy((char *) htup + htup->t_hoff,
    5789                 :      21474 :            (char *) tuple->t_data + tuple->t_data->t_hoff,
    5790                 :            :            newlen);
    5791                 :            : 
    5792                 :      10737 :     MarkBufferDirty(buffer);
    5793                 :            : 
    5794                 :            :     /* XLOG stuff */
    5795         [ +  - ]:      10737 :     if (RelationNeedsWAL(relation))
    5796                 :            :     {
    5797                 :            :         xl_heap_inplace xlrec;
    5798                 :            :         XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    5799                 :            : 
    5800                 :      10737 :         xlrec.offnum = ItemPointerGetOffsetNumber(&tuple->t_self);
    5801                 :            : 
    5802                 :      10737 :         XLogBeginInsert();
    5803                 :      10737 :         XLogRegisterData((char *) &xlrec, SizeOfHeapInplace);
    5804                 :            : 
    5805                 :      10737 :         XLogRegisterBuffer(0, buffer, REGBUF_STANDARD);
    5806                 :      10737 :         XLogRegisterBufData(0, (char *) htup + htup->t_hoff, newlen);
    5807                 :            : 
    5808                 :            :         /* inplace updates aren't decoded atm, don't log the origin */
    5809                 :            : 
    5810                 :      10737 :         recptr = XLogInsert(RM_HEAP_ID, XLOG_HEAP_INPLACE);
    5811                 :            : 
    5812                 :      10737 :         PageSetLSN(page, recptr);
    5813                 :            :     }
    5814                 :            : 
    5815                 :      10737 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    5816                 :            : 
    5817                 :      10737 :     UnlockReleaseBuffer(buffer);
    5818                 :            : 
    5819                 :            :     /*
    5820                 :            :      * Send out shared cache inval if necessary.  Note that because we only
    5821                 :            :      * pass the new version of the tuple, this mustn't be used for any
    5822                 :            :      * operations that could change catcache lookup keys.  But we aren't
    5823                 :            :      * bothering with index updates either, so that's true a fortiori.
    5824                 :            :      */
    5825         [ +  - ]:      10737 :     if (!IsBootstrapProcessingMode())
    5826                 :      10737 :         CacheInvalidateHeapTuple(relation, tuple, NULL);
    5827                 :      10737 : }
    5828                 :            : 
    5829                 :            : #define     FRM_NOOP                0x0001
    5830                 :            : #define     FRM_INVALIDATE_XMAX     0x0002
    5831                 :            : #define     FRM_RETURN_IS_XID       0x0004
    5832                 :            : #define     FRM_RETURN_IS_MULTI     0x0008
    5833                 :            : #define     FRM_MARK_COMMITTED      0x0010
    5834                 :            : 
    5835                 :            : /*
    5836                 :            :  * FreezeMultiXactId
    5837                 :            :  *      Determine what to do during freezing when a tuple is marked by a
    5838                 :            :  *      MultiXactId.
    5839                 :            :  *
    5840                 :            :  * NB -- this might have the side-effect of creating a new MultiXactId!
    5841                 :            :  *
    5842                 :            :  * "flags" is an output value; it's used to tell caller what to do on return.
    5843                 :            :  * Possible flags are:
    5844                 :            :  * FRM_NOOP
    5845                 :            :  *      don't do anything -- keep existing Xmax
    5846                 :            :  * FRM_INVALIDATE_XMAX
    5847                 :            :  *      mark Xmax as InvalidTransactionId and set XMAX_INVALID flag.
    5848                 :            :  * FRM_RETURN_IS_XID
    5849                 :            :  *      The Xid return value is a single update Xid to set as xmax.
    5850                 :            :  * FRM_MARK_COMMITTED
    5851                 :            :  *      Xmax can be marked as HEAP_XMAX_COMMITTED
    5852                 :            :  * FRM_RETURN_IS_MULTI
    5853                 :            :  *      The return value is a new MultiXactId to set as new Xmax.
    5854                 :            :  *      (caller must obtain proper infomask bits using GetMultiXactIdHintBits)
    5855                 :            :  */
    5856                 :            : static TransactionId
    5857                 :      19013 : FreezeMultiXactId(MultiXactId multi, uint16 t_infomask,
    5858                 :            :                   TransactionId relfrozenxid, TransactionId relminmxid,

    5860                 :            :                   uint16 *flags)

    6008                 :            :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_DATA_CORRUPTED),
    6009                 :            :                          errmsg_internal("found update xid %u from before relfrozenxid %u",
    6010                 :            :                                          xid, relfrozenxid)));
    6011                 :            : 
    6012                 :            :             /*
    6013                 :            :              * It's an update; should we keep it?  If the transaction is known
    6014                 :            :              * aborted or crashed then it's okay to ignore it, otherwise not.
    6015                 :            :              * Note that an updater older than cutoff_xid cannot possibly be
    6016                 :            :              * committed, because HeapTupleSatisfiesVacuum would have returned
    6017                 :            :              * HEAPTUPLE_DEAD and we would not be trying to freeze the tuple.
    6018                 :            :              *
    6019                 :            :              * As with all tuple visibility routines, it's critical to test
    6020                 :            :              * TransactionIdIsInProgress before TransactionIdDidCommit,
    6021                 :            :              * because of race conditions explained in detail in
    6022                 :            :              * heapam_visibility.c.
    6023                 :            :              */
    6024   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             if (TransactionIdIsCurrentTransactionId(xid) ||
    6025                 :          0 :                 TransactionIdIsInProgress(xid))
    6026                 :            :             {
    6027                 :            :                 Assert(!TransactionIdIsValid(update_xid));
    6028                 :          0 :                 update_xid = xid;
    6029                 :            :             }
    6030         [ #  # ]:          0 :             else if (TransactionIdDidCommit(xid))
    6031                 :            :             {

    6033                 :            :                  * The transaction committed, so we can tell caller to set

    6038                 :          0 :                 update_committed = true;
    6039                 :          0 :                 update_xid = xid;

    6043                 :            :                 /*
    6044                 :            :                  * Not in progress, not committed -- must be aborted or
    6045                 :            :                  * crashed; we can ignore it.
    6046                 :            :                  */
    6047                 :            :             }
    6048                 :            : 
    6049                 :            :             /*
    6050                 :            :              * Since the tuple wasn't marked HEAPTUPLE_DEAD by vacuum, the
    6051                 :            :              * update Xid cannot possibly be older than the xid cutoff. The
    6052                 :            :              * presence of such a tuple would cause corruption, so be paranoid
    6053                 :            :              * and check.
    6054                 :            :              */
    6055   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             if (TransactionIdIsValid(update_xid) &&
    6056                 :          0 :                 TransactionIdPrecedes(update_xid, cutoff_xid))
    6057         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 ereport(ERROR,

    6065                 :            :              * members of the new Multi, in case we end up using that.  (We
    6066                 :            :              * might still decide to use only an update Xid and not a multi,
    6067                 :            :              * but it's easier to maintain the list as we walk the old members
    6068                 :            :              * list.)
    6069                 :            :              */
    6070         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (TransactionIdIsValid(update_xid))
    6071                 :          0 :                 newmembers[nnewmembers++] = members[i];
    6072                 :            :         }
    6073                 :            :         else

    6075                 :            :             /* We only keep lockers if they are still running */
    6076   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             if (TransactionIdIsCurrentTransactionId(members[i].xid) ||

    6078                 :            :             {

    6090                 :            :     {
    6091                 :            :         /* nothing worth keeping!? Tell caller to remove the whole thing */
    6092                 :          0 :         *flags |= FRM_INVALIDATE_XMAX;

    6095 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     else if (TransactionIdIsValid(update_xid) && !has_lockers)

    6099                 :            :          * without creating a new Multi.  (XXX we could do this when there's a
    6100                 :            :          * single remaining locker, too, but that would complicate the API too
    6101                 :            :          * much; moreover, the case with the single updater is more
    6102                 :            :          * interesting, because those are longer-lived.)
    6103                 :            :          */

    6111                 :            :     {
    6112                 :            :         /*
    6113                 :            :          * Create a new multixact with the surviving members of the previous
    6114                 :            :          * one, to set as new Xmax in the tuple.
    6115                 :            :          */
    6116                 :          0 :         xid = MultiXactIdCreateFromMembers(nnewmembers, newmembers);
    6117                 :          0 :         *flags |= FRM_RETURN_IS_MULTI;
    6118                 :            :     }

    6120                 :          0 :     pfree(newmembers);
    6121                 :            : 
    6122                 :      19013 :     return xid;
    6123                 :            : }
    6124                 :            : 
    6125                 :            : /*
    6126                 :            :  * heap_prepare_freeze_tuple
    6127                 :            :  *
    6128                 :            :  * Check to see whether any of the XID fields of a tuple (xmin, xmax, xvac)
    6129                 :            :  * are older than the specified cutoff XID and cutoff MultiXactId.  If so,
    6130                 :            :  * setup enough state (in the *frz output argument) to later execute and
    6131                 :            :  * WAL-log what we would need to do, and return true.  Return false if nothing
    6132                 :            :  * is to be changed.  In addition, set *totally_frozen_p to true if the tuple
    6133                 :            :  * will be totally frozen after these operations are performed and false if
    6134                 :            :  * more freezing will eventually be required.
    6135                 :            :  *
    6136                 :            :  * Caller is responsible for setting the offset field, if appropriate.
    6137                 :            :  *
    6138                 :            :  * It is assumed that the caller has checked the tuple with
    6139                 :            :  * HeapTupleSatisfiesVacuum() and determined that it is not HEAPTUPLE_DEAD
    6140                 :            :  * (else we should be removing the tuple, not freezing it).
    6141                 :            :  *
    6142                 :            :  * NB: cutoff_xid *must* be <= the current global xmin, to ensure that any
    6143                 :            :  * XID older than it could neither be running nor seen as running by any
    6144                 :            :  * open transaction.  This ensures that the replacement will not change
    6145                 :            :  * anyone's idea of the tuple state.
    6146                 :            :  * Similarly, cutoff_multi must be less than or equal to the smallest
    6147                 :            :  * MultiXactId used by any transaction currently open.
    6148                 :            :  *
    6149                 :            :  * If the tuple is in a shared buffer, caller must hold an exclusive lock on
    6150                 :            :  * that buffer.
    6151                 :            :  *
    6152                 :            :  * NB: It is not enough to set hint bits to indicate something is
    6153                 :            :  * committed/invalid -- they might not be set on a standby, or after crash
    6154                 :            :  * recovery.  We really need to remove old xids.
    6155                 :            :  */
    6156                 :            : bool
    6157                 :     106979 : heap_prepare_freeze_tuple(HeapTupleHeader tuple,
    6158                 :            :                           TransactionId relfrozenxid, TransactionId relminmxid,
    6159                 :            :                           TransactionId cutoff_xid, TransactionId cutoff_multi,
    6160                 :            :                           xl_heap_freeze_tuple *frz, bool *totally_frozen_p)
    6161                 :            : {
    6162                 :     106979 :     bool        changed = false;
    6163                 :     106979 :     bool        xmax_already_frozen = false;
    6164                 :            :     bool        xmin_frozen;
    6165                 :            :     bool        freeze_xmax;
    6166                 :            :     TransactionId xid;
    6167                 :            : 
    6168                 :     106979 :     frz->frzflags = 0;
    6169                 :     106979 :     frz->t_infomask2 = tuple->t_infomask2;
    6170                 :     106979 :     frz->t_infomask = tuple->t_infomask;
    6171                 :     106979 :     frz->xmax = HeapTupleHeaderGetRawXmax(tuple);
    6172                 :            : 
    6173                 :            :     /*
    6174                 :            :      * Process xmin.  xmin_frozen has two slightly different meanings: in the
    6175                 :            :      * !XidIsNormal case, it means "the xmin doesn't need any freezing" (it's
    6176                 :            :      * already a permanent value), while in the block below it is set true to
    6177                 :            :      * mean "xmin won't need freezing after what we do to it here" (false
    6178                 :            :      * otherwise).  In both cases we're allowed to set totally_frozen, as far
    6179                 :            :      * as xmin is concerned.
    6180                 :            :      */
    6181         [ +  + ]:     106979 :     xid = HeapTupleHeaderGetXmin(tuple);
    6182         [ +  + ]:     106979 :     if (!TransactionIdIsNormal(xid))
    6183                 :        585 :         xmin_frozen = true;
    6184                 :            :     else
    6185                 :            :     {
    6186         [ -  + ]:     106394 :         if (TransactionIdPrecedes(xid, relfrozenxid))
    6187         [ #  # ]:          0 :             ereport(ERROR,
    6188                 :            :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_DATA_CORRUPTED),
    6189                 :            :                      errmsg_internal("found xmin %u from before relfrozenxid %u",
    6190                 :            :                                      xid, relfrozenxid)));
    6191                 :            : 
    6192                 :     106394 :         xmin_frozen = TransactionIdPrecedes(xid, cutoff_xid);
    6193         [ -  + ]:     106394 :         if (xmin_frozen)
    6194                 :            :         {
    6195         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (!TransactionIdDidCommit(xid))
    6196         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 ereport(ERROR,
    6197                 :            :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_DATA_CORRUPTED),
    6198                 :            :                          errmsg_internal("uncommitted xmin %u from before xid cutoff %u needs to be frozen",
    6199                 :            :                                          xid, cutoff_xid)));
    6200                 :            : 
    6201                 :          0 :             frz->t_infomask |= HEAP_XMIN_FROZEN;
    6202                 :          0 :             changed = true;
    6203                 :            :         }
    6204                 :            :     }
    6205                 :            : 
    6206                 :            :     /*
    6207                 :            :      * Process xmax.  To thoroughly examine the current Xmax value we need to
    6208                 :            :      * resolve a MultiXactId to its member Xids, in case some of them are
    6209                 :            :      * below the given cutoff for Xids.  In that case, those values might need
    6210                 :            :      * freezing, too.  Also, if a multi needs freezing, we cannot simply take
    6211                 :            :      * it out --- if there's a live updater Xid, it needs to be kept.
    6212                 :            :      *
    6213                 :            :      * Make sure to keep heap_tuple_needs_freeze in sync with this.
    6214                 :            :      */
    6215                 :     106979 :     xid = HeapTupleHeaderGetRawXmax(tuple);
    6216                 :            : 
    6217         [ +  + ]:     106979 :     if (tuple->t_infomask & HEAP_XMAX_IS_MULTI)
    6218                 :            :     {
    6219                 :            :         TransactionId newxmax;
    6220                 :            :         uint16      flags;
    6221                 :            : 
    6222                 :      19013 :         newxmax = FreezeMultiXactId(xid, tuple->t_infomask,
    6223                 :            :                                     relfrozenxid, relminmxid,
    6224                 :            :                                     cutoff_xid, cutoff_multi, &flags);
    6225                 :            : 
    6226                 :      19013 :         freeze_xmax = (flags & FRM_INVALIDATE_XMAX);
    6227                 :            : 
    6228         [ -  + ]:      19013 :         if (flags & FRM_RETURN_IS_XID)
    6229                 :            :         {
    6230                 :            :             /*
    6231                 :            :              * NB -- some of these transformations are only valid because we
    6232                 :            :              * know the return Xid is a tuple updater (i.e. not merely a
    6233                 :            :              * locker.) Also note that the only reason we don't explicitly
    6234                 :            :              * worry about HEAP_KEYS_UPDATED is because it lives in
    6235                 :            :              * t_infomask2 rather than t_infomask.
    6236                 :            :              */
    6237                 :          0 :             frz->t_infomask &= ~HEAP_XMAX_BITS;
    6238                 :          0 :             frz->xmax = newxmax;
    6239         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (flags & FRM_MARK_COMMITTED)
    6240                 :          0 :                 frz->t_infomask |= HEAP_XMAX_COMMITTED;
    6241                 :          0 :             changed = true;
    6242                 :            :         }
    6243         [ -  + ]:      19013 :         else if (flags & FRM_RETURN_IS_MULTI)
    6244                 :            :         {
    6245                 :            :             uint16      newbits;
    6246                 :            :             uint16      newbits2;
    6247                 :            : 
    6248                 :            :             /*
    6249                 :            :              * We can't use GetMultiXactIdHintBits directly on the new multi
    6250                 :            :              * here; that routine initializes the masks to all zeroes, which
    6251                 :            :              * would lose other bits we need.  Doing it this way ensures all
    6252                 :            :              * unrelated bits remain untouched.
    6253                 :            :              */
    6254                 :          0 :             frz->t_infomask &= ~HEAP_XMAX_BITS;
    6255                 :          0 :             frz->t_infomask2 &= ~HEAP_KEYS_UPDATED;
    6256                 :          0 :             GetMultiXactIdHintBits(newxmax, &newbits, &newbits2);
    6257                 :          0 :             frz->t_infomask |= newbits;
    6258                 :          0 :             frz->t_infomask2 |= newbits2;
    6259                 :            : 
    6260                 :          0 :             frz->xmax = newxmax;
    6261                 :            : 
    6262                 :      19013 :             changed = true;
    6263                 :            :         }
    6264                 :            :     }
    6265         [ +  + ]:      87966 :     else if (TransactionIdIsNormal(xid))
    6266                 :            :     {
    6267         [ -  + ]:      68315 :         if (TransactionIdPrecedes(xid, relfrozenxid))
    6268         [ #  # ]:          0 :             ereport(ERROR,

    6364                 :            : 
    6365                 :            : /*
    6366                 :            :  * heap_execute_freeze_tuple
    6367                 :            :  *      Execute the prepared freezing of a tuple.
    6368                 :            :  *
    6369                 :            :  * Caller is responsible for ensuring that no other backend can access the
    6370                 :            :  * storage underlying this tuple, either by holding an exclusive lock on the
    6371                 :            :  * buffer containing it (which is what lazy VACUUM does), or by having it be
    6372                 :            :  * in private storage (which is what CLUSTER and friends do).
    6373                 :            :  *
    6374                 :            :  * Note: it might seem we could make the changes without exclusive lock, since
    6375                 :            :  * TransactionId read/write is assumed atomic anyway.  However there is a race
    6376                 :            :  * condition: someone who just fetched an old XID that we overwrite here could
    6377                 :            :  * conceivably not finish checking the XID against pg_xact before we finish
    6378                 :            :  * the VACUUM and perhaps truncate off the part of pg_xact he needs.  Getting
    6379                 :            :  * exclusive lock ensures no other backend is in process of checking the
    6380                 :            :  * tuple status.  Also, getting exclusive lock makes it safe to adjust the
    6381                 :            :  * infomask bits.
    6382                 :            :  *
    6383                 :            :  * NB: All code in here must be safe to execute during crash recovery!
    6384                 :            :  */
    6385                 :            : void
    6386                 :       2378 : heap_execute_freeze_tuple(HeapTupleHeader tuple, xl_heap_freeze_tuple *frz)
    6387                 :            : {
    6388                 :       2378 :     HeapTupleHeaderSetXmax(tuple, frz->xmax);
    6389                 :            : 
    6390         [ -  + ]:       2378 :     if (frz->frzflags & XLH_FREEZE_XVAC)
    6391                 :          0 :         HeapTupleHeaderSetXvac(tuple, FrozenTransactionId);
    6392                 :            : 
    6393         [ -  + ]:       2378 :     if (frz->frzflags & XLH_INVALID_XVAC)
    6394                 :          0 :         HeapTupleHeaderSetXvac(tuple, InvalidTransactionId);
    6395                 :            : 
    6396                 :       2378 :     tuple->t_infomask = frz->t_infomask;
    6397                 :       2378 :     tuple->t_infomask2 = frz->t_infomask2;
    6398                 :       2378 : }
    6399                 :            : 
    6400                 :            : /*
    6401                 :            :  * heap_freeze_tuple
    6402                 :            :  *      Freeze tuple in place, without WAL logging.
    6403                 :            :  *
    6404                 :            :  * Useful for callers like CLUSTER that perform their own WAL logging.
    6405                 :            :  */

    6563                 :            : /*

    6576                 :            : 
    6577                 :            : /*
    6578                 :            :  * Does the given multixact conflict with the current transaction grabbing a
    6579                 :            :  * tuple lock of the given strength?
    6580                 :            :  *
    6581                 :            :  * The passed infomask pairs up with the given multixact in the tuple header.
    6582                 :            :  *
    6583                 :            :  * If current_is_member is not NULL, it is set to 'true' if the current
    6584                 :            :  * transaction is a member of the given multixact.
    6585                 :            :  */
    6586                 :            : static bool
    6587                 :     384153 : DoesMultiXactIdConflict(MultiXactId multi, uint16 infomask,
    6588                 :            :                         LockTupleMode lockmode, bool *current_is_member)
    6589                 :            : {
    6590                 :            :     int         nmembers;

    6593                 :     384153 :     LOCKMODE    wanted = tupleLockExtraInfo[lockmode].hwlock;
    6594                 :            : 
    6595 [ +  - ][ +  + ]:     384153 :     if (HEAP_LOCKED_UPGRADED(infomask))

    6596                 :          0 :         return false;
    6597                 :            : 
    6598                 :     384153 :     nmembers = GetMultiXactIdMembers(multi, &members, false,
    6599 [ +  + ][ -  + ]:     384153 :                                      HEAP_XMAX_IS_LOCKED_ONLY(infomask));
    6600         [ +  - ]:     384153 :     if (nmembers >= 0)
    6601                 :            :     {
    6602                 :            :         int         i;
    6603                 :            : 
    6604         [ +  + ]:    2430734 :         for (i = 0; i < nmembers; i++)
    6605                 :            :         {

    6607                 :            :             LOCKMODE    memlockmode;

    6617                 :            :             {

    6619                 :      29985 :                     *current_is_member = true;

    6622         [ +  + ]:    1999712 :             else if (result)
    6623                 :      48491 :                 continue;
